title: Future Returns: There’s Still Opportunity in Emerging Market Stocks
text:
Text size

Emerging markets investors can’t take it anymore. For two months they’ve been bailing out of mutual funds and ETFs, taking cover from what has been a stomach-wrenching stretch of volatility and uncertainty about the stability of the global economy.

The fact remains, however, that emerging market stocks continue to be an important asset class for investors who want to maintain a diversified long-term portfolio. That’s investing 101. But how should investors reconcile that basic lesson with their impulse to flee and wait for calmer times?

Rather than closing out emerging markets in your portfolio, consider trimming exposure somewhat—there’s good reason to keep a foot in the door, says James Donald, head of emerging markets for Lazard Asset Management in New York.

“In emerging markets, you have 20% to 30% discounts in stock price-to-earnings valuations compared to developed markets, and profitability that is not far away from developed markets,” Donald says. “It is complicated, no question, but we think it’s a relatively attractive time to be in emerging markets.”

Think Long Term

Emerging markets stocks started out strong this year, posting double-digit increases through April. But that’s when trade tensions flared up between the U.S. and China, threatening to slow world economic growth, and markets began gyrating wildly and losing ground.

Emerging markets are particularly sensitive to trade tensions because they are highly dependent on growth in the world economy. “Emerging markets tend to do well when trade is expanding,” Donald says. “And investors are anxious that trade will not be expanding—that it will be contracting.”

And there are other uncertainties, such as the strength of the U.S. dollar, which was already putting strain on emerging markets heading into the trade war. Emerging markets generally don’t do well when the dollar is strong. While the dollar has eased somewhat, it’s uncertain how big a factor it will be in the months ahead, Donald says.

“It’s a bit hard to tell because half the time [President Donald] Trump is talking about how great the U.S. economy is and how strong the dollar is, and half the time he seems to want to depress the value of the dollar,” Donald says.

While it’s easy to get elbow-deep in all of the factors impacting the market in the short term, investors shouldn’t lose sight of the fact that emerging markets play an important role in a long-term diversified portfolio.

While the asset class has been underperforming for almost a decade, “if you look at history, you don’t have constant underperformance. You have periods of underperformance followed by periods of outperformance,” Donald says.

“Twenty years ago, people were extremely gloomy about emerging markets and a lot of people said, ‘This is where you have a lot of volatility and no return,’” Donald says. “The next 10 years was a period where you got much better returns.”

Assuming the U.S. and China can settle a comprehensive trade deal, “I wouldn’t be surprised at all if we’re not far from a period where emerging markets start becoming an outperforming asset class.”

Avoid Trouble Spots

In the meantime, select stock picking is important, both geographically and across sectors. There are a number of trouble spots best avoided, Donald says.

For example, last week, just weeks before a general election, Standard & Poor’s slashed Argentina’s long-term credit rating by three notches, pushing the country further toward a financial crisis. South Africa’s economy has yet to regain firm footing under President Cyril Ramaphosa, who took office in February last year. And Mexico “is a bit of a concern,” Donald says, citing uncertainties about the country’s new president Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador.

On the positive side, however, there are a number of countries that inspire confidence, including India and Indonesia, where there are signs of infrastructure investments not unlike China’s some 20 to 25 years ago. And Eastern European countries have seen banking industry growth and credit growth, Donald says.

Broadly speaking, the most successful sector in emerging markets lately has been internet-related technology companies based in China, Korea, and Taiwan, while there’s also been some strong performance in consumer staples and healthcare stocks, Donald says.

These areas tend to have high valuations, while the more economically sensitive sectors such as financials, industrials, and energy are quite cheap.

“If the world economy stabilizes and we avoid global recession, there’s reason to believe some more economically sensitive areas that are depressed could do significantly better,” Donald says. “The financial position of a lot of these companies is pretty good—we’ve seen quite an improvement in balance sheets as a result of companies making profits and paying dividends.”

While the three sectors—financials, industrials and energy—are the ones to watch, “we look at things very much stock by stock—it’s a bit like finding a needle in a haystack,” Donald says.

Extreme volatility is likely to continue in emerging markets for some time. The key is to keep a long term view and remember that the asset class can also perform very differently than the U.S. and developed markets when current scenarios are flipped—when today’s stronger markets weaken, emerging markets could be the asset class that buoys your portfolio’s performance.
description: Lazard Asset Management’s James Donald on why it’s important to keep a foot in the door, even in turbulent times
